intro: Galium subvillosum, commonly known as hairy bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender stems and opposite leaves covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers in clusters, typically blooming from June to August. Its leaves are usually ovate to lanceolate in shape and have a slightly hairy texture. Galium subvillosum is often found in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges.
